Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Duality-based tools for simple vs. optimal mechanism design and applications to cryptocurrency

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Traditionally, we think of algorithms as "processing an input" in order to "produce an output." For example, imagine a firm trying to allocate various resources among its employees: It might solicit from each employee how each resource affects their productivity (the "input"), and allocate the resources in a way to maximize the total production (the "output"). When each user has the same goal (maximize the firm's productivity), the traditional algorithmic paradigm perfectly captures the firm's objective. 

What if instead we wish to model a cloud computing service allocating various resources among its users? Now, the goals of the individual users (maximize their own productivity) are misaligned with that of the service. Therefore, users may manipulate whatever algorithm is deployed in order to improve their own productivity, possibly at the cost of others'. Properly designing solutions for such domains inevitably requires mechanism design, which makes use of both algorithmic and game theoretic tools. As part of this project, the PI is developing a new undergraduate course "Economics and Computation" in order to provide the next generation of computer scientists with the ability to reason rigorously about the incentives of users who interact with their systems. 

Much prior work prescribes wildly complex mechanisms which are unusable in practice, motivating prior work of the PI and others to investigate the theoretical properties of simple mechanisms. The main research focus of this project is to greatly expand our understanding of how to appropriately deploy simple mechanisms, via a rigorous theoretical foundation. As part of this project, the PI will continue giving talks and tutorials about the specific approach used to obtain these new results, referred to as a "duality theory." 

A secondary focus of this project is to apply these theoretical foundations to resolve cryptocurrency incentive issues arising within Bitcoin, an emerging cryptocurrency. While Bitcoin has remained largely immune to traditional security breaches, numerous incentive issues have been discovered which could undermine its future security if not properly addressed. As part of this project, the PI will help broaden participation by other mechanism designers in this direction via tutorials. 

In a little more detail, the main research focus of this project aims to answer questions such as "what properties of a setting make simple mechanisms appropriate or inappropriate?" or "Quantitatively, how 'complex' does a mechanism need to be in order to be 'close' to optimal?" The main technical ingredient in this approach is a novel duality framework recently developed by the PI and co-authors. The secondary focus aims specifically to make progress towards an incentive compatible cryptocurrency protocol: one where all users are incentivized to follow the protocol in earnest, even when their refusal to do so goes undetected. While the PI's focus will be on the theoretical foundations of such a protocol, any findings will be followed up by experimental (simulations) or empirical (data) research as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project develops an algorithmic toolkit for modern settings, where these algorithms interact with strategic users. It considers domains such as ad auctions: billions of automated interactions take place daily, but advertisers, users, and the platform have competing interests. It also considers cryptocurrencies: economic transactions are authorized by millions of self-interested users, rather than a centralized authority. 


Intellectual merit:

The project completes three thrusts: two related to auction design, and a third related to cryptocurrencies.


In the first thrust, this project develops the first approximation scheme for revenue-optimal multi-item auctions. More specifically, this result allows the user to trade off additional computation for stronger theoretical guarantees: more work results in a greater guaranteed fraction of the theoretical optimum. Moreover, for any fixed fraction of the theoretical optimum (even 99%, or 99.9%), the solution is computationally tractable.


In the second thrust, this project provides the first separation between the communication complexity of algorithms for honest users and mechanisms for strategic users. Specifically, we show that it is possible for two player to communicate very little but still successfully allocate goods between them when both players are honest. Yet, any protocol achieving the same guarantee when both players are strategic requires an exponential increase in communication between the players.


In the final thrust, this project considers incentive issues in cryptocurrencies. Specifically we show that that incentive-driven attacks on Bitcoin are significantly strong against systems which replace proof-of-work with proof-of-stake, or block reward with transaction fees (but are otherwise similar to Bitcoin). 


Broader Impacts:
This project develops connections between Computer Science and adjacent fields such as Economics and Operations Research. Multiple papers produced during this project are published in top journals in these fields, and the PI presented these works at Economics workshops and seminars. 


Through this project, the PI co-organized three consecutive mentoring workshops, co-located with Economics and Computation (the flagship conference at the intersection of Economics and Computer Science) from 2018 - 2020. These workshops welcomed new junior researchers to the EC community. Through this project, the PI directly mentored dozens of undergraduate reseachers, and several PhD students as well.


Through this project, the PI participated in the reading group Mechanism Design for Social Good (MD4SG), and served on the PC for all their workshops and the first conference. This emerging research agenda aims to connect researchers in the EC community with technical expertise with those who do work in social good.
